critique: The document is an executive order from 1941 restricting civil service examinations for federal employees without departmental consent during an emergency. Ideologically, it's hard to place on a left-right spectrum (+0) as it relates to government efficiency during a crisis. It doesn't directly address immigration (-0). It arguably expands executive power (+2) by giving the Civil Service Commission more authority during an emergency, although it does have an end date contingent on the end of the emergency. It centralizes power at the federal level (+1) as it dictates rules for federal employees. It leans towards national security (+1) by prioritizing government efficiency during an emergency. It could be seen as interventionist (+1) as it restricts employee movement. It doesn't directly address social inclusion (+0). Upon further reflection, the expansion of executive power is moderate, as it is tied to an emergency and has a sunset clause. The national security aspect is also moderate, as it is about government efficiency rather than direct security measures. The interventionist aspect is also moderate, as it is a temporary measure during an emergency.
